titleStmt.title: The fruits of faith in these five famous men, scripture worthies Heb:XI.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. titleStmt.title: The fruits of faith in these five famous men, scripture worthies Heb:XI.

publicationStmt.publisher: Are to be sould by Rich: Tompson in Bedford streete against the New Exchange,

notesStmt.note: Date and place of publication from Wing.
Extracts from scripture illustrating the lives of Enoch, Noah, Abraham, Joseph and Moses, and also the "pictures of a new borne Christian." With drawings of the five patriarchs.--Thomason catalogue.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

2007-12 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.head: THE FRVITS OF FAITH IN THESE FIUE FAMOUS Men, SCRIPTURE WORTHIES HEB: XI.

figure.head: Enoch.
figure.p: By faith Enoch was tranſlated that hee ſhould not ſee death: etc: for before his tranſlation he had this teſtimonie that hee pleaſed God. vers. 5.

figure.head: Noah.
figure.p: By faith Noah being warned of God of things not ſeen as yet, moved with feare prepared an ark to ye ſaving of his houſe etc. v. 7.

figure.head: Abraham.
figure.p: By faith Abraham when he was called to go out etc. obeyed and went out not knowing whither he went and he ſojourned in the land of promiſe etc. v. 8. 9.

figure.head: Joſeph.
figure.p: By faith Joſeph when he died (in Egipt) made mention of the departing of the children of Iſrael, and gave commandment concerning his bones. v. 12.

figure.head: Moſes.
figure.p: By faith Moſes when he was come to yeers refuſed to he called the ſon of Pharaohs daughter, chuſing rather to ſuffer affliction etc. v. 24. 25.

div.head: THE PICTURE OF A NEW BORNE CHRISTIAN DRAWNE BY THE SCRIPTUR'S TRUE PROPORTION, IN TWENTY FOUR INFALLIBLE CHARACTERS.

p.label: 1. Of his new Birth.
p.q: Except a man bee Borne againe he cannot injoy God being Borne againe of incorruptable ſeed, 1 pet. 1. 23.
Whoſoeuer is borne of God he cannot ſin, 1. John 3. 9.
cast not the childrens bread to dogs, Math. 15. 26.

p.label: 2. of his new Foode.
p.q: I haue eſteemed his word more then my neceſsary food Job. 23. 12
How ſweete are thy words vnto my taſte? pſal. 119. 103
As chriſts, ſo in the meaſure received the chriſtian his meatis to do the will of his father Joh. 4. 34.

p.label: 3. of his Growth.
p.q: may grow up into him in all things Eph. 4. 15.
As new borne babes deſire the ſincere milk of the word to grow thereby, 1. pet. 1. 2.
But they grow in grace and in knowledge, 1. pet. 1. 2.

p.label: 4. his Apparell
p.q: Hath put on the armour of light Rom: 13. 12
And of righteouſneſs. 2. Cor. 6. 7.
the whole armor of God Ephe: 6: 11.

p.label: 5. his inward man
p.q: Thy word haue I hid in my hart pſal. 119. 11:
Your life is hid with Chriſt in God Colo: 3. 3.
but let it be the hidden man of the hart ſtrengthned with might by his ſpirit. etc. Ep: 3. 16

p.label: 6. his will.
p.q: for to will is preſent with me Ro: 7. 18.
with good will doing ſervice as to ye Lord for if there be firſt a willing minde it is accepted. etc. 2. Cor: 8. 12.

div.p:
7. his Conſcience alwayes a conſcience void of offence toward God and toward men Act. 24: 16. Holding faith and a good conſcience. 1 Tim. 1. 19
with the teſtimony of our conſcience ſerving god 2. Co 1. 12

p.label: 8. his Loue.
p.q: o how I love thy law, yea aboue fine gold. Pſal: 119.
love worketh none ill, love is the fulfilling of the law. Rom: 13. 10.

p.label: 9. his Hatred.
p.q: I hate every falſe way pſal. 119. 104.
hate the evil loue the good Amos. 5. 15.
do good to them that hate you Mat: 5. 44.
therefore the world hateth you John. 15. 19

p.label: 10. his Feare.
p.q: who deſire to feare thy name Nehe: 1. 11.
therefore will not wee feare though the earth be removed Pſal. 46. 2.
a book of remembrance was written for them. Mal. 3. 16

p.label: 11. his Confidence
p.q: And have no confidence in the fleſh Phil: 3. 3.
Wee hold fast the confidence firm unto the end Heb: 3. 6.
caſt not away your confidence which hath great recompence Heb. 10. 35.

p.label: 12. his Joy.
p.q: Yet I will rejoyce in the Lord: I will joy in the God of my ſalvation. Habak: 3. 28.
and your joy no man taketh from you Jo: 16. 22.
It is joy to the juſt to do judgment Pro: 21: 15.

div.p:
13. his Grief but they are grieved for the affliction of Joſeph And grieve not the holy ſpirit of God. Eph. 4. 30.
Surely he hath borne our griefs, Iſa. 53. 4

p.label: 14. his Patience
p.q: Who by patient continuance in well-doing ſeek for glory, and honour, Rom. 1. 7.
and let us run with patience Heb. 12. 1.
let patience have her perfect work, ſa. 1. 4.

p.label: 15. his Anger.
p.q: Ceaſe from anger, and forſake wrath: fret not thy ſelfe in any wiſe to do evil. Pſal. 37. 8.
be angry and ſin not Eph. 4. 26. put of anger wrath malice etc.

p.label: 16. his outward man
p.q: Let not ſin reign therefore in your mortall body etc: Rom. 6. 12.
but if ye through the ſpirit do mortifie the deeds of the body Rom: 8. 13

div.p:
17. his Hearing. take heed how ye hear Luk. 8. 28.
take heed what ye hear. my ſheep hear my voice Joh. 10. 27.
faith cometh by hearing Ro. 10. 17.

p.label: 18. his Eyes.
p.q: I was eyes to the blinde Job. 29. 15.
the eyes of the lord are in every place beholding the evil and the good Pro. 15. 3.
bleſsed are the eyes which ſee Luk. 10. 23.

p.label: 19. his Tongue.
p.q: not double tongued. 1. Tim. 3. 8.
Who ſo keepeth his tongue keepeth his ſoul: pr: 21
The tongue of the Juſt is as choice ſilver Pro. 10. 20.

p.label: 20. his Eating.
p.q: and eateth not the bread of idleneſs. pr: 32.
They ſhall eate and praiſe the Lord Iſa. 62. 9
Thou ſhalt eat the labour of thine hands Pſal. 128. 2.

p.label: 21. his Hands.
p.q: He that, 〈◊〉 hath clean hands and a pure hart, pſal. 24. 4.
lifting vp holy hands. 1. Tim. 2. 8.
work with your own hands. 1. Theſ. 4. 11.

p.label: 22. his Feete.
p.q: Keep thy foot when thou goest to the houſe of God. Eccl. 5. 1.
make ſtrait paths for your feet. Heb. 12. 13
if thy foot offend thee cut it of. mat. 18. 8.

p.label: 23. his Company.
p.q: I am a companion of all them that feare thee. pſal. 119. 63.
not to company with fornicators. 1. Cor. 5. 9
note yt man and have no company. etc 2 Th. 3. 11

p.label: 24. his Death.
p.q: Pretious in the ſight of the Lord, pſ. 116. 15.
on ſuch the ſecond death hath no power. Rev. 25
He yt overcometh ſhall not be hurt of the ſecond death Rev. 2. 11.
